newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany opposes immediate EU arable aid cut.
newsitem.headline: Germany opposes immediate EU arable aid cut.

text.p: Germany rejected plans by the EU Commission to cut arable area and set-aside compensatory payments under farm reform to help support beef farmers, a Bonn farm ministry official said on Wednesday.
Bonn would plead for a delay in this EU decision until next spring when the budget situation becomes clearer, Ralf Kosmetschke of the ministry's grain department said at a harvest conference.
EU ministers will discuss the proposal to cut such payments by 7.3 percent at a September 16-17 Farm Council.
"These payments were meant to be permanent and safe and March and April usually show some leeway in the EU budget," Kosmetschke said.
He acknowledged Germany eventually might make some concessions on farm support, both under WTO pressure and plans to integrate eastern European countries into the EU.
But he warned that radical cuts in these payments would threaten grain and oilseeds output and incomes at small and medium-sized farms which are prevalent in western Germany.
"Studies show fixed costs of producting grain at 240-260 marks a tonne which necessitate additional support payments," he said.
"Cuts in farm support would threaten the role of the EU as a net exporter of grain." --Vera Eckert, Hamburg newsroom, +49-40-41903275
